title: Season 7 should be about attracting new players
body:
I, for one, am perfectly happy with season 6 going down in history as a season of uncertainty and experimentation. Hopefully by the end of it Riot will resolve the soloq/dynq issues and come up with a good blend of the two, so they can focus on a different, but very important issue:

League can benefit from an influx of fresh blood. As it is, old players are becoming burned out on league, starting to quit it and even hate on it. And that's perfectly okay. Few games, if any, can boast keeping a player's interest for so long, and renewing it with every major update. 

Keeping old players is a good pursuit, but sometimes there just isn't anything a company can do. The 2k games diamond 4 player who uninstalled sometimes just wants to play something else for a while, or maybe forever. Doesn't matter. There just needs to be an eager newbie taking his place in order for the game to stay fresh and alive.

As it stands, League is very unwelcoming to new players. I don't even think smurfs are as problematic as the sheer amount of stuff to learn and the little to no assistance provided by Riot to new players. It's all an outdated, confusing mess. I think in the season to come, Riot should focus on reeling new players in through intriguing stories, champions and thorough introductions to the gameplay of League.

Thanks for reading and best of luck in your games!{{sticker:slayer-jinx-catface}}

That's exactly what the retcon is for. They _aren't_ fighting in the League. The games we play are basically _literally games_, bloodsports conducted with summoners ( yes, they still exist, they're just not part of Runeterra anymore ) that call forth what are basically phantoms of the "legends" or otherwise notable people of Valoran and beyond. Certain things may hint at lore events, but just like they are OOCly, they're basically set dressing to make the world of the "game" seem more alive.

It's exactly the same deal as with, say, DOTA or Overwatch, just without the actual "justification." Yes, with DOTA, there is this whole "battle of the Ancients" going on in the lore, but it's comically always sometime in the future, a conflict put on the heroes' schedules ( literally, in the case of Rylai ) but not one to ever come. That's because the actual gameplay does not suit the lore _at all_, and trying to do so would raise way more questions than it would answer or just flat-out break the game. Overwatch may  have locations and missions that'll end up being important to the characters, and they may interact in ways that would be true to how they'd interact in the situation they're in, but they're still absolutely _no_ reason for Tracer to help Widowmaker push an EMP device onto a camp of Omnics in her hometown, much less _Bastion_ or _Zenyatta_ who would also be killed in the blast - and Zenyatta is flat-out a monk of peace that promotes human-Omnic equality! Hell, Blizzard has flat-out stated that the gameplay of Overwatch is completely out of the story, because there's just really no making sense of it.

But OW still has Overwatch (the organization) to tie all of the characters together. Even if lore and gameplay don't mix, its silly to say that none of the characters have a reason for being there. They specifically describe each and every hero's reason for joining Overwatch. 

_____________

DotA was a custom map for an RTS that just grew and grew and grew. Them not having any ties means nothing because there isn't any story for DotA, in actuality. They're just a bunch of new units tossed into a custom game, essentially. DotA 2 is just a prettier version of it. 

Also, all of the heroes are on the same level, power-wise. They're all beings, not gods. Even Zues, a literal god, reduced himself to being mortal due to an argument with his wife. 
___________________

League, like Overwatch, had an organization that tied everything together, gave champions a purpose for being there. Not anymore.

But Riot's still trying to flesh out the world like anything makes sense anymore?

Then you have different champions in League, many of which are irrefutably much, much stronger or larger than others in lore, but they're all magically on the same playing field/unit of measurement? **Why do we have a giant star dragon, that literally forges massive celestial stars, that's barely bigger than Gragas? ** There's no fixing that. Riot fucked up. Aurelion Sol is a massive failure simply because of that small fact. He will never deliver as a character because he **is not** the character in lore. That's just a similarly themed character, not the character that lore describes.  

I'm sorry but if you take a game like League without completely re-doing all the lore all at once, you're left with nothing. It doesn't matter how much they flesh out certain regions. The lore of the game is forever broken because so much of it just doesn't keep up with the rest. 

It also doesn't help that Riot made a bad habit of including power in lore, rather than primarily characterization.

Actually, the organization of Overwatch explains less than you might think, based on the title. Are there characters in Overwatch, in-universe? Well, yeah. But what about Widowmaker and Reaper, who work _for Overwatch's enemies_? Well, I guess you can say they're "meant" to be on the other team from the Overwatch heroes ... even though they're basically the only ones. But what about Hanzo? Pharah? Bastion? Junkrat? D.Va? Roadhog? Zarya? Lucio? Symmetra? Zenyatta? Maybe you can claim they're all people that the members of Overwatch could've picked up as teammates as part of the scenario of the mission, or that some of them would flat-out join the organization ... but there's another thing: Overwatch, in-universe, is basically dismantled. Agents of Overwatch were "recalled," but overall most of the stuff for Overwatch agents are likely unusable, because _Overwatch activity is illegal_.

There's ... actually really nothing Overwatch provides the actual in-game stuff, besides the background of quite a few characters and explanations of why they interact with each other the way that they do, and also I guess it provided a reason why one stage looks like it does.

Also, the heroes of DOTA definitely aren't the same power level. Sure, there's nothing to the level of, say, Teemo vs. Aurelion Sol ... because it's even worse. You've got Techies, three goblin-esque things that are based around explosives _and nothing else_, facing off against the _fundamental forces of the universe_, including _gravity_, _electromagnetic force_, and _weak_ and _strong nuclear force_. No, not someone that channels the forces for their powers, not some god that has power over those forces, _the embodiment of those forces themselves_.

And, yes, the Techies can lay down some land mines and blow them to smitheroons, no problem. Hell, they can blow themselves up and commit suicide _and then proceed to come back to life sooner than a fundamental force of the universe_.

And that's not all. Funny that you mentioned Aurelion Sol, because in DOTA a really, _really_ angry troll with a lot of tomahawks is actually one of the best heroes to kill and destroy another hero that is _literally a star_. A random kobold-goblin thing that is flat-out posed as an underdog and really only has cloning to his name - a skill that many other heroes have, anyway - can curbstomp _the heat death of the universe itself_ with a shovel. And last but not least, a yellow guy riding a bat ... can douse _the creator of the world itself_ in napalm and burn him to death.

So ... yeah, DOTA definitely has the same problems as League, if not worse, in terms of heroes being of the same power level and said power level be represented in-game.

That last sentence makes no sense, Aurelion Sol is a very well written character with a clear personality and set of goals.   The Ascended are extremely enticing characters, they are still relatable despite their power, which is a sign of extremely good storytelling.  

The game we play has nothing to do with the story.  The champions are exactly as the name of the game implies: Legends from the world of Runeterra.  You're thinking about it all wrong,  the game and the lore are separate, Summoner's Rift is like Final Destination in Smash, it's just where characters go to fight.  Going on the Smash analogy, think of League as a bunch of toys, some shaped like dragons{{champion:136}} , some like ordinary people{{champion:51}} .  The Summoners are the child that plays with the toys.  One of the toys may be of a great and powerful being{{champion:75}} , but it's still just the same as a figure with a shotgun{{champion:104}} : a toy.  That's what Riot is going for, the characters have a backstory so you know who exactly you're commanding in game, but the backstory may have nothing to do with the game at all.

The Smash analogy falls apart when you consider the fact that, unlike smash, Riot is trying to build the world that they lived in behind the game, and apparently they were all during relatively similar time periods within the world. 

Not some false arena some omnipotent god-finger created for them to fight in. That would make more sense than what Riot's trying to do now.

In the sense of Lore, Riot got out of one cage because they felt it was for the better...then spearheaded right into another.

I actually believe lore retcon was a good thing, but they still fucked up. 

Yes, before all the characters had a reason to fight in league. But that actually limited pool of new champions they were adding. Not gonna lie, i wasn't reading lore that much, but i don't believe champions like Annie or Nidalee had a real reason to fight in League. I remember i read someone's lore once and thought "This reason to join league is sucked out of the finger".
I also thought maybe lore retcon will allow to add more "protector" type of champions - who don't really want to fight, but do so only to protect what they love. These characters would need some stupid reason to join league like "He believes that in league arena he can do more for his family than anywhere else".
Third reason you said already - powerful beings. They don't have a place in league, so they only can be mentioned through something not entirely game related.

So, i think removing Institute of War was a good thing. BUT the way they done it is stupid.
Just saying "Summoners are no longer canon" is terrible idea. I was hoping they will make a whole universe now. They kinda done that... but only kinda. So i know there are a lot of locations in the world, but I'm not sure how they are tied together. I see Braum - i know that guy is from Freljord. I see Azir - i know he is from Shurima. While i know they are from the same universe, i still don't feel like they are from the same universe. They can be from completely different worlds, because nothing really ties them together.

Institute of War was connecting different characters together. Now this connection is broken. and nothing replaced it. I wanted Riot to create a new world, a whole universe of interesting characters, something global, something even bigger than "Wheel of Time" book series. But they failed miserably. Instead, they created a bunch of small groups, which are not connected to each other at all.

I never said it didn't need changes, just that it was done very poorly; on that note I agree. Things did need changes if they wanted to get out of the cage they built, but expanding it would have made a lot more sense than dismantling it. There's literally no reason for the demi-gods to associate with the mortals in this game anymore...yet there they are. They're still trying to build the world even though there's no reason for the game to be taking place in it now?

They would have been better off making the summoners' magic more and more powerful. Essentially force people to take part in their conflicts. Make it so the Institute literally was a part of everyone's lives...unnaturally so. That would give reason for these gods and demi-gods being there, even outside of imprisonment. It also would have moved the scope of the game's lore from the Institute of war to the entire world they were trying to build. Maybe even beyond, not even including those from beyond that would flock to Runeterra for glory, conquest, curiosity, or, like bard, to prevent calamity. 

Power attracts power, even if there's a wide variety of intentions associated with it.

Well, now when you said it, I really feel they should have done it your way. Current state of the Runeterra is like Bahamas - couple of lore made islands, without deep connections between them. I've never been a big fun of this game's lore, but i am definitely a fan of alternative universes, which are big and consist of different nations, races and, of course, have magic involved! Their current attemts to make lore looks like a fanfiction to me: lots of words, little to no use.

I've been playing this game a long time, damn near since the beginning and I've got to say it's largely the new players that are ruining the game, and by new players I'm mostly referring to anyone that joined around S4-now. 

People take the game too seriously now. It's all about abusing what's powerful and copy pasting whatever the pros are doing. No one thinks for themselves anymore, no one plays to have fun. Competitive drive is great and all, but not at the expense of fun. I'm sure I'm not the only one that's been more frustrated with a win than happy from time to time.

As a fellow veteran i partly agree - on one hand, you are right people have been going full copy pasta since halfway through Season 4. On the other hand, i find the experienced players create more problems in the game - mainly through smurfing. Sure, smurfs quickly end up getting matched only against each other, which of course is nice - but this also breeds more toxicity, which in turn results in more smurfs for various reasons. The community has been on a steady decline ever since Season 5 begun, and then it jumped off a cliff with Season 6. 

We can only hope Riot learns from their massive mistake this season, instead of taking it to another next level in half a year's time.

On the bright side, at this rate we might soon be back to the good old days with a small, concentrated playerbase.

Smurfs have always been a huge problem. Thinking back to when I first started, nearly every game I was in had one person just dumpstering everyone on the enemy team. I don't think that's an exclusively veteran player problem though. On the contrary, I definitely know more new players with multiple accounts than I do old players. I don't know if this is the case for all veterans, but I see no reason to make a new account when this one has everything unlocked. 

Also, the problem with smurfing is that it's not against the rules. Back in the day, it was against the rules to abuse the refer a friend thing, but the account itself wasn't breaking a rule, just referring yourself was. Another thing that's sort of amplifying the problem is how popular smurfing has become. It's gotten to the point where people watch streams of master tier people absolutely demolishing silver players in an effort to show that elo hell doesn't exist is very popular, as well as 'racing' to see how fast you can get your smurf where your main is. 

As for getting back to the small playerbase of the good ol' days, I fear that's no longer an option. Even if the game dies out to that point, as long as there are pros to copy, that's what people will do. The birth of LoL as an eSport has killed originality.
